questions.question: We went out in spite of the rain.
questions.description: The given sentence has only one finite verb and hence one clause. So it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: Do you think she is ready?
questions.description: The given sentence has a main clause and a subordinate clause. Hence, it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: I am anxious to contact him.
questions.description: The given sentence has only one finite verb and hence one clause. So it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: I noticed that he seemed to be drinking a lot.
questions.description: The given sentence has a main clause and a subordinate clause. Hence, it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: He came to Sydney to look for work.
questions.description: The given sentence has only one finite verb and hence one clause. So it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: My father was bitten by a dog last week.
questions.description: The given sentence has only one finite verb and hence one clause. So it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: I don’t know what I should do.
questions.description: The given sentence has a main clause and a subordinate clause. Hence, it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: I neither smoke nor drink.
questions.description: The given sentence has two co-ordinate clauses connected by the correlative conjunction neither/nor. Hence it is a compound sentence.

questions.question: I didn’t sing because she was there.
questions.description: The given sentence has a main clause and a subordinate clause. Hence, it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: You can stay or quit.
questions.description: The given sentence has two coordinate clauses connected by the coordinating conjunction or.

questions.question: If it helps, I will lend you some money.
I knocked again and again but nobody opened the door.
questions.description: The given sentence has two coordinate clauses connected by the coordinating conjunction but.
